{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11272,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Psilocarphus brevissimus, commonly known as woolly marbles, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in well-drained soils. When caring for this plant, it is important to provide minimal watering. Generally, watering once every two weeks should be sufficient, especially if the environment is naturally dry. Be careful to avoid over-watering, as it can lead to root rot. During its dormant period, reduce watering and allow the soil to dry out almost completely. Observe the plant for signs of water stress and adjust watering accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psilocarphus brevissimus prefers full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. If grown in an area that is too shady, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent sunburn, although the plant generally tolerates high temperatures well. Ensure that the plant has enough space around it for good air circulation, which helps prevent mold and mildew in shadier spots."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Psilocarphus brevissimus is not typically necessary, as it is a small and compact perennial. However, you can perform light pruning to remove dead or damaged stems to encourage healthier growth. If you wish to shape the plant or remove any unwanted growth, it is best done in the early spring before the main growing season. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to minimize the risk of disease transmission. Regular monitoring will help you decide if any additional trimming is needed to maintain the plant's appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"low woolly marbles","description":"Psilocarphus brevissimus is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common names short woollyheads, woolly marbles, and woolly heads.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["low woolly marbles"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Psilocarphus brevissimus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is quite drought tolerant and should not be overwatered. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings, especially during its dormant period in winter. During the growing season, water it sparingly, typically once every two weeks, or adjust based on the rainfall and climate conditions in your area. Overwatering can lead to root rot and should be avoided to maintain a healthy plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias asperula prefers full sun to thrive, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. However, you can remove spent flower heads to encourage more blooms and prevent unwanted self-seeding if that is a concern. Cut back the stems to about four to six inches above the ground in late fall after the first frost, or in early spring. This helps promote vigorous new growth for the coming season. Also, remove any broken or diseased stems whenever noticed to maintain the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Antelopehorn Milkweed","description":"Asclepias asperula is a species of milkweed native to the Southwestern United States and northern Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10373,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erysimum capitatum, also known as Western Wallflower, prefers well-drained soil and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering in winter when the plant's growth slows down. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot, which can harm the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erysimum capitatum thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant blooms, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensuring enough sunlight will help maintain its compact growth and enhance flower production, contributing to a healthier, more vigorous plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erysimum capitatum is essential to encourage healthy growth and plentiful blooms. Deadheading spent flowers during the blooming season will stimulate the plant to produce more flowers. Lightly trim the plant in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and maintain its shape. Avoid pruning too aggressively, as this can reduce blooming. In late fall, remove any remaining dead foliage to tidy the plant for winter, but avoid cutting into the plant’s main structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Wallflower","description":"Erysimum capitatum is a species of wallflower known commonly as the sanddune wallflower, western wallflower, or prairie rocket.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Western Wallflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Erysimum capitatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10676,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brassica nigra, commonly known as black mustard, prefers consistent moisture but is not overly demanding in its water needs. It thrives well with regular watering, especially during dry spells or in containers where soil can dry out faster. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Water deeply but less frequently to encourage deep root growth. A good practice is to check the soil surface; if it feels dry to touch, it’s time to water. Avoid overhead watering to reduce the risk of disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brassica nigra prefers full sun conditions, meaning it thrives with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This ensures robust growth and the production of healthy foliage and flowers. If grown in partial shade, the plant may become leggy as it stretches towards the light, and its flowering may be reduced. Ensure the planting location receives ample sunlight daily, especially in cooler climates where full sun will aid faster growth. In very hot regions, slight afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brassica nigra is generally minimal, as the plant does not require frequent trimming. Remove any yellowing or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and to prevent the spread of potential diseases. If the plant starts to get too tall or leggy, you can trim back the stems to promote bushier growth and more robust flowering. Pinch out the flower stems if you want to prevent self-seeding, as black mustard can spread quickly in the right conditions. Regularly deadheading can also help prolong the flowering period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Mustard","description":"Brassica nigra, or black mustard, is an annual plant cultivated for its black or dark brown seeds, which are commonly used as a spice. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11572,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phoradendron juniperinum, also known as mistletoe, is a parasitic plant typically found growing on host trees and shrubs. Because it derives moisture from its host, it requires minimal direct watering when cultivated independently. However, if grown indoors or in a controlled environment, ensure the soil is consistently moist but never waterlogged. Water sparingly during the winter months when the plant's growth naturally slows down. Aim to use lukewarm water to prevent shocking the plant, ensuring it drains completely to avoid root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phoradendron juniperinum favors bright, indirect sunlight when in a cultivation setting, mimicking its natural growth in tree canopies. Direct sunlight can be too intense, potentially scorching its leaves. In a controlled growing environment indoors, placing it near a south or east-facing window provides adequate light exposure without direct rays. If grown under shade outdoors, it benefits from dappled sunlight, similar to what it would naturally receive among its host's branches. Ensure it receives at least 6 hours of indirect light daily to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Phoradendron juniperinum when it is in its natural parasitic environment. However, when cultivated, light pruning may be beneficial to control size and shape, and to remove any dead or diseased parts. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, which help minimize stress and potential disease entry points. Pruning can also encourage bushier growth, as it stimulates new branching."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Juniper Mistletoe","description":"Phoradendron juniperinum is a species of flowering plant in the sandalwood family known by the common name juniper mistletoe. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it grows in various types of woodland habitat. It has been reported from California, Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Texas, Chihuahua and Sonora.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Juniper Mistletoe"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Phoradendron juniperinum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11177,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galinsoga quadriradiata, commonly known as Peruvian daisy or hairy galinsoga, prefers consistent moisture in its soil but does not like to be waterlogged. Water this plant moderately and make sure the soil is well-drained. During its active growing season, which is typically spring and summer, ensure the plant receives adequate water to keep the soil slightly moist, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering frequency in fall and winter, allowing the plant to rest while ensuring it does not completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sunlight and will perform best when it receives at least 6 hours of direct light per day. Galinsoga quadriradiata can tolerate partial shade, but it will likely produce fewer flowers and exhibit leggier growth under these conditions. When grown in optimal sunlight conditions, the plant will display a more compact form with abundant blooms. If cultivated indoors or in a location with limited sunlight, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure sufficient light exposure for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Galinsoga quadriradiata is not always necessary since it is primarily grown as an annual. However, if you choose to manage its growth or shape, you can do so by pinching back the stems to encourage bushier growth and prevent legginess. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can promote a longer flowering period and prevent the plant from setting seed, which helps to control its spread, as it can be quite invasive. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to maintain plant health and prevent disease. During dry periods, provide supplementary watering to keep the soil evenly moist, especially in the first year after planting as the plant establishes itself. Once established, Ajuga can tolerate brief dry spells, but consistent watering will encourage lush growth and vibrant blooms. In general, checking the soil moisture level by touching it a couple of inches deep is a good practice to avoid both underwatering and overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ajuga genevensis thrives in partial to full sun. The adaptability of Ajuga to varying light conditions makes it a versatile ground cover choice."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ajuga genevensis is relatively straightforward. The key is to balance light exposure to encourage robust growth without subjecting the plant to excessive heat or light stress, which could hamper its blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fuchsia boliviana is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging prolific blooming. Prune in early spring before the plant's active growing season begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches and pinch back the tips of healthy stems to promote bushier growth. During the flowering period, deadheading, or removing spent blooms, will encourage further flowering. Avoid heavy pruning in the fall, as this plant should conserve energy heading into its semi-dormant winter stage. Regular pruning helps manage its size and enhances the overall health of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lady's eardrops","description":"Fuchsia boliviana is a species of Fuchsia native to southern Peru, Bolivia and northern Argentina.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Bolivia","Peru"],"other_name":["lady's eardrops"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Fuchsia boliviana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10576,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera aliciae, or Alice sundew, requires consistently moist soil to thrive. It's best to use distilled or rainwater to avoid mineral buildup, as tap water can harm the plant. The soil should be kept damp but not waterlogged, so a tray method works well—filling a shallow tray with water to allow the plant to draw moisture from the bottom. Reduce watering slightly in winter, but never let the soil completely dry out. Always ensure excess water can drain to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera aliciae prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight for several hours a day can be beneficial, but too much can cause leaf burn. In an indoor setting, a south-facing window is ideal, but be mindful of intense midday sun. In lower light conditions, supplemental lighting with a fluorescent or LED grow light can help maintain vibrant growth. Ensure the plant receives about 12-14 hours of light daily for optimal photosynthesis and dew production, crucial for its trapping mechanism."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Drosera aliciae involves removing dead or dying leaves to encourage healthy growth and maintain its appearance. Use sterilized scissors to trim these leaves close to the base. This not only prevents decay but also reduces the risk of mold. Regular pruning helps the plant allocate nutrients to new growth, aiding its overall vitality. As a sundew, it benefits from undisturbed roots, so handle the plant gently, and focus pruning efforts only on the foliage, not the roots or central growth point."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alice Sundew","description":"Drosera aliciae, the Alice sundew, is a carnivorous plant in the family Droseraceae. It’s important to water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is evenly wet. However, allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, the plant may require more frequent watering, particularly if the weather is hot and dry. In contrast, reduce watering during fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always water at the base of the plant to avoid wetting the foliage, which can lead to disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Motherwort thrives in conditions with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure optimal growth. While the plant can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and spindly growth. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent scorching and stress on the plant. Place the plant in a bright location, and if growing indoors, ensure it is near a south or west-facing window to receive adequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is an essential aspect of caring for Leonurus cardiaca to encourage bushier growth and remove dead or unhealthy parts of the plant. Regularly trim back the plant after it flowers to prevent it from becoming leggy and to promote further blooms. In the fall, you can cut the plant back to about half its height to prepare it for winter. Remove any sick, damaged, or dead stems throughout the year to maintain plant health. Pruning not only keeps the plant looking tidy but also improves air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common motherwort","description":"Leonurus cardiaca, known as motherwort, is an herbaceous perennial plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae. Other common names include throw-wort, lion's ear, and lion's tail. Lion's tail also being a common name for Leonotis leonurus, and lion's ear, a common name for Leonotis nepetifolia. Originally from Central Asia and southeastern Europe, it is now found worldwide, spread largely due to its use as a herbal remedy.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["common motherwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Leonurus cardiaca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the blooming period is over, you may also cut back any dead or unsightly foliage to maintain a neat appearance. In colder climates, leaving the stems can provide winter interest and habitat for insects, cutting back only in early spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"fire poppy","description":"Papaver californicum is a species of poppy known by the common names fire poppy and western poppy.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["fire poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Papaver californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular harvesting of mature specimens helps prevent rot and encourages more fruiting, thus effectively managing your fungal harvest without pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"chicken of the woods","description":"Laetiporus sulphureus is a species of bracket fungus (fungi that grow on trees) found in Europe and North America. Its common names are crab-of-the-woods, sulphur polypore, sulphur shelf, and chicken-of-the-woods. Its fruit bodies grow as striking golden-yellow shelf-like structures on tree trunks and branches. To achieve this, the plant should be placed in a tray of distilled water or rainwater, keeping the water level just below the pot rim to maintain swamp-like conditions. Ensure that the soil remains moist at all times, particularly during the growing season, to mimic its natural habitat for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera anglica thrives in full sunlight, necessitating at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure enhances the plant's health, vigor, and encourages the production of the mucilaginous droplets that characterize the sundew's leaves. If growing indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window or providing additional fluorescent lighting can replicate these conditions. Care should be taken to avoid too much intensity during extremely hot periods which can lead to leaf burn, though generally, this plant is well-adapted to sunny conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a significant requirement for Drosera anglica as it involves less conventional pruning. However, it is beneficial to occasionally remove dead or blackened leaves using sterilized scissors to encourage healthy new growth and prevent mold. During dormancy or when the plant shows signs of dying back, avoid extensive pruning as new growth will emerge from the roots in the growing season. Being a lichen, it absorbs moisture directly from the environment. Therefore, providing a humid environment can be beneficial. Avoid direct watering and ensure that the air around it maintains adequate moisture. If indoors, occasionally misting the air around the lichen can help maintain the right humidity levels. Over-watering directly onto the lichen should be avoided as it does not absorb water like regular plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parmelia sulcata prefers bright, indirect sunlight. In nature, it thrives on exposed surfaces such as trees and rocks where light is plentiful but not overly intense. If kept indoors, placing it near a window that receives indirect sunlight or in a space with filtered light can simulate its natural conditions. Avoid placing it in direct sunlight for prolonged periods, as this can cause desiccation or damage to the lichen. It appreciates fluctuating light conditions similar to those found in natural environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is typically not necessary for Parmelia sulcata as it is a lichen, which grows differently than typical plants. However, to maintain its aesthetic appearance, you may gently clean or remove any damaged bits or debris that might have settled on it. Take care not to scrape or damage the lichen's body during this process. Regularly check for signs of decay or dead portions and carefully trim them away to keep the lichen healthy and encourage natural growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"shield lichen","description":"Net-marked parmelia (Parmelia sulcata), or shield lichen, is a foliose lichen in the family Parmeliaceae. It harbours a unicellular Trebouxia green algal symbiont.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["shield lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Parmelia sulcata"],"soil":["Rocky","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10277,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scutellinia scutellata, commonly known as eyelash cup fungus, doesn't require watering like traditional plants since it is a fungus. It naturally grows in damp and moist environments, often found on decaying wood, soil, and forest debris. If you are cultivating this fungus for study or interest, ensure the surrounding environment is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged, resembling a forest floor's conditions. Mist the area regularly if kept in a terrarium or similar setting to prevent drying out, but avoid creating standing water which could lead to mold or bacterial growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scutellinia scutellata thrives in shaded or dappled light conditions, similar to its natural forest floor habitat. It does not require direct sunlight and in fact may desiccate if exposed to intense light. If grown in a controlled environment like a terrarium, indirect light or filtered sunlight will suffice. Mimic natural light conditions typical of wooded or moistened environments to encourage healthy growth. It’s crucial to balance light exposure with humidity, ensuring neither overpower the delicate structures of this unique fungus. A north-facing window or shaded location is typically ideal for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not necessary for Scutellinia scutellata as it is a fungus and not a plant with leaves or branches that require trimming. However, if cultivating, ensure to remove any other decaying material or unwanted fungal growth that might compete with or overshadow the Scutellinia scutellata. Keeping the environment clean and debris-free will allow you to better observe and enjoy its unique cup-like structure. Excessive handling should be avoided as it is a delicate organism. Focus on maintaining its habitat for optimal growth and health rather than direct pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Eyelash","description":"Scutellinia scutellata, commonly known as the eyelash cup, the Molly eye-winker, the scarlet elf cap, the eyelash fungus or the eyelash pixie cup, is a small saprophytic fungus of the genus Scutellinia. It is the type species of Scutellinia, as well as being the most common and widespread. The fruiting bodies are small red cups with distinct long, dark hairs or \"eyelashes\". These eyelashes are the most distinctive feature and are easily visible with a magnifying...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Common Eyelash"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Scutellinia scutellata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11377,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nemophila parviflora prefers consistent moisture in the soil. It should be watered regularly, especially during dry spells, ensuring the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged. Mulching can help retain soil moisture. Be attentive not to let the plant dry out completely, as this can stress it. Water early in the morning or late in the afternoon to reduce evaporation. During cooler months or when rainfall is adequate, you can reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nemophila parviflora thrives best in areas with partial shade, as full sun can often be too intense for this plant and cause the foliage to wilt or burn. Ideally, it should be positioned where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade or dappled sunlight throughout the day. This mimics its natural woodland habitat, allowing it to flourish without the stress of excessive heat. In hotter climates, too much direct sunlight should be avoided to prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nemophila parviflora typically does not require extensive attention, as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, to encourage bushier growth and prolong blooming, you can pinch back the tips of the stems when the plant is young. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can help prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively and can also encourage continued blooming. Regularly remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health and aesthetics."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"small-flowered nemophila","description":"Nemophila parviflora, the smallflower nemophila, small-flowered nemophila or oak-leaved nemophila, is a dicot in the borage family, Boraginaceae, in the waterleaf subfamily, Hydrophylloideae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["small-flowered nemophila"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Nemophila parviflora"],"soil":["Loamy","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10476,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus parvifolius, commonly known as the native raspberry, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. It is important to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. During dry spells or periods of drought, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the plant does not suffer from dehydration. However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. A good approach is to water thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus parvifolius thrives best when it receives full sun, meaning it should ideally get 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun conditions encourage more vigorous growth and increased fruit production. In shaded locations, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers and fruits. Ensuring the plant gets enough light also helps in minimizing disease issues by promoting faster drying of foliage after rain. For optimal growth, place Rubus parvifolius in a position that receives unobstructed sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus parvifolius is essential for maintaining healthy growth and maximizing fruit production. Pruning should be done in late winter or early spring while the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes to prevent disease spread and encourage new growth. Thin out the center of the plant to improve air circulation and light penetration. Additionally, trim back any overgrown canes to maintain the desired shape and size of the plant. Summer pruning may also be necessary to remove any suckers or excess growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"small-leaf bramble","description":"Rubus parvifolius, called Japanese bramble, or Australian raspberry in the United States or native raspberry in Australia is a species of plants in the rose family. It is a scrambling shrub native to eastern Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam) and Australia. It has also become naturalized in a few scattered locations in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["small-leaf bramble"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rubus parvifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11575,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allium fimbriatum, commonly known as the fringed onion, requires moderate watering. During its active growing season in spring, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. It is important to reduce watering significantly in summer when the plant enters dormancy. Overwatering during its dormant phase can lead to bulb rot. Therefore, allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions during this period. Using well-draining soil helps prevent overwatering issues, contributing to bulb health and longevity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium fimbriatum thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant can tolerate some shade, but excessive shade may reduce flowering and weaken the plant. When grown in sunnier locations, the plant develops stronger stems and more vibrant blossoms. If situated in a region with particularly intense afternoon sun, partial shading can help to prevent leaf scorch. Ensure its location is open with good air circulation for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Allium fimbriatum mainly involves the removal of spent flower stems and yellowing leaves. After the plant has bloomed, wait until the flower heads wilt and turn brown before cutting them off. This practice helps the plant conserve energy for the next growing season. Removing the dead foliage in fall is also recommended, as it tidies up the plant and minimises disease risks. When pruning, always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant and to prevent the spread of any diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Onion","description":"Allium fimbriatum is a species of wild onion known by the common name fringed onion. It is native to California and Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Fringed Onion"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Allium fimbriatum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10376,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Delphinium nudicaule, commonly known as the canyon delphinium, prefers moderate watering. During the growing season in spring and early summer, ensure the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in late summer and fall when the plant becomes dormant. It's crucial to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In well-drained soils, this plant can be relatively drought tolerant once established but performs best with consistent moisture during its active growth period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Delphinium nudicaule thrives best in full sunlight, but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Morning sunlight can be especially beneficial, providing the necessary energy for growth while protecting it from harsher afternoon sun. In very hot regions, partial shade during the afternoon may help prevent leaf scorch and stress. Providing ample sunlight helps ensure robust growth and vibrant flowering, which is a key aspect of caring for this plant effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not strictly necessary for Delphinium nudicaule, but it can be beneficial for maintaining plant health and appearance. After the flowers have faded, deadhead by cutting back the flower stalks to encourage a tidy appearance and potentially prompt a second flowering. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems and foliage to promote healthy new growth. It's important to use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission. Avoid cutting into the basal rosette of leaves as this can harm the plant's regenerative ability."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red larkspur","description":"Delphinium nudicaule, known by the common names canyon larkspur, red larkspur, orange larkspur, and canyon delphinium, is a flowering perennial herb in the Buttercup Family (Ranunculaceae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["Red larkspur"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Delphinium nudicaule"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11773,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Romulea bulbocodium prefers well-drained soil and does not tolerate waterlogging. Water the plant moderately during its growing season, typically in spring and autumn. Allow the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. During its dormant period in summer, reduce watering significantly and let the soil dry out completely to mimic its natural habitat. Over-watering can lead to bulb rot. If planted outdoors, in areas with moderate rainfall, supplemental watering may not be necessary. Always ensure proper drainage in pots or garden beds to prevent stagnant water around the bulbs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Romulea bulbocodium thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal blooming and healthy growth, provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. Planting in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade can be beneficial, especially in regions with intense afternoon heat. If grown indoors or in containers, place the plant in a south or west-facing window where it can receive adequate sunlight. During its dormant period in summer, reduced light is acceptable, but during active growth, ensure it gets plenty of light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is minimal for Romulea bulbocodium. During its growing season, you can remove any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them at the base with clean scissors. After the flowering period, allow the plant's foliage to die back naturally, as the leaves are essential for energy storage in the bulbs. Do not cut back the leaves while they are still green to ensure the bulbs are well-nourished for the next blooming cycle. If grown in garden beds, ensure that you remove any weeds that may compete with the plant for nutrients and space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Crocus-leaved romulea","description":"Romulea bulbocodium is one of the best-known species from the genus Romulea. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant, but light shaping can be done to maintain the desired size and form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western azalea","description":"Rhododendron occidentale, the western azalea or California azalea, is one of two deciduous Rhododendron species native to western North America (the other is Rhododendron albiflorum). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10973,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tremellodendropsis tuberosa, also known as the \"Tuberous Coral Fungus,\" typically thrives in moist environments. When cultivating or encountering this fungus in natural habitats like woodlands, ensure the substrate remains consistently damp. However, be cautious not to oversaturate, as excessive water can lead to unfavorable conditions such as mold or fungal diseases. Maintaining ambient humidity can also support its growth. If planted or kept in controlled settings, mimicking natural rain patterns with occasional water misting can help maintain the right moisture level. Regularly check the soil or substrate to ensure it doesn't dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tremellodendropsis tuberosa is usually found in shaded or partially shaded environments. In its natural habitat, it tends to grow under the forest canopy where it receives filtered sunlight. When cultivating this fungus, ensure it is not exposed to direct sunlight, as this can dry out the substrate and harm its growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11982,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Narcissus poeticus, commonly known as poet's narcissus, requires well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to bulb rot. During its active growing season in spring, water regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Reduce watering after the flowering period as the plant enters dormancy over the summer. In fall and winter, minimal watering is needed, as natural rainfall typically suffices. Ensure that the soil is only slightly moist during dormancy, particularly if rainfall is scarce. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases, watering at the base of the plant instead."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Narcissus poeticus thrives in full or partial sunlight. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the blooms from wilting prematurely. The plant prefers an open location where sunlight can reach all parts of it, ensuring even growth and flowering. If grown indoors or in shaded gardens, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. For optimal blooms and healthy plants, position Narcissus poeticus in an area with ample sunlight, particularly in the morning and early afternoon hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Narcissus poeticus involves removing spent blooms to prevent the plant from using energy to produce seeds, encouraging it to store nutrients in the bulbs for next year's growth. Deadheading should be done immediately after the flowers fade by snipping the stem near the base without cutting the leaves. Allow the foliage to remain until it yellows and withers naturally, as it continues photosynthesis needed to recharge the bulb. Only remove leaves after they have fully died back. Avoid tying or braiding the leaves, as this can restrict their ability to photosynthesize effectively and may damage the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Poet's Narcissus","description":"Narcissus poeticus (poet's daffodil, poet's narcissus, nargis, pheasant's eye, findern flower, and pinkster lily) was one of the first daffodils to be cultivated, and is frequently identified as the narcissus of ancient times (although Narcissus tazetta and Narcissus jonquilla have also been considered as possibilities). It is also often associated with the Greek legend of Narcissus. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant, considering its natural adaptation to challenging coastal environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly beachheather","description":"Hudsonia tomentosa is a species of flowering plant in the rockrose family known by the common names woolly beachheather, beach heather, and sand heather. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote healthy growth and good berry production. In areas with lower light availability, expect possibly reduced vigor and berry yield. Ensure it is planted in a location that provides consistent exposure to the sun as too much shade might impair its growth and overall robustness. Full sunlight exposure also aids in maintaining its attractive foliage and form throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Schinus molle is essential for maintaining its shape and health, typically performed in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This tree can grow large with a spreading canopy, so pruning may also be necessary to manage size and prevent it from becoming invasive in some regions. Regularly remove suckers growing from the base and lightly trim any overreaching branches. During the growing season, frequent watering is beneficial, but in the winter months, reduce the watering frequency as the plant’s growth slows. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus parviflorus thrives in partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where protection from the afternoon sun is beneficial. If planted in too much shade, the plant may produce fewer flowers and fruits. Full sun conditions can enhance flower and fruit production, but ensure that the plant is not subjected to scorching and drying conditions by providing partial shelter if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus parviflorus is essential for maintaining its health and encouraging robust growth. After the plant flowers, it is best to prune immediately to remove dead or weak stems, which can help improve air circulation. Thinning out older canes will allow new, more vigorous canes to establish. Aim to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning keeps the plant looking tidy and prevents it from becoming overly dense, which can make it more susceptible to pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"thimbleberry","description":"Rubus parviflorus, commonly called thimbleberry, is a species of Rubus native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["thimbleberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Cane Borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rubus parviflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
